Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.As we approach the end of a year that has been unlike any other, I’m sure some of your readers, like myself, will be thinking of those we hold dear who are unable to join the family Christmas meal this year.I’d like to suggest a simple, last-minute gt that will help connect people in Argyll and Bute with their loved ones and feed hungry children around the world.Mary’s Meals, a charity reaching more than . million children every day in some of the world’s poorest countries, is hosting a virtual Christmas dinner. For just £. – enough to feed a child every day for an entire school year – your readers can set a place at our table for their friends and family. Their name will appear online and we’ll provide a digital placemat to pass on as a present.This year, your gts will go twice as far, with each place set now feeding two children with Mary’s Meals for an entire school year.Give until January  and public donations will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £ million – meaning we can reach even more hungry children in Liberia with le-changing school meals.Daniel Adams, executive director of Mary#s Meals UK.It can be frightening and lonely for young people when they leave the care system. Many may be living on their own for the first time and often will not have a network of friends and family around to offer them support.Christmas can be a particularly dficult and isolating time for care leavers as they find themselves having to spend the festive season on their own, especially this year when Covid- restrictions mean it will be dficult to go out to socialise and the usual large-scale Christmas dinners for care leavers will not be taking place.However, the charity Family Action runs Listening Works, a free virtual helpline specically for young care leavers aged  to  years old across the UK. We are here all evening, every evening pm to midnight and even over the festive period, December  to January , we are still available from pm to pm.So,you are a care leaver, whether you’ve got something on your mind or you just fancy a friendly chat, we’re here for you when many other services are shut or not available.You can call us on   , text us on    or you can have a web chat with us via our website at www.family-action.org.uk listening-works – whatever kind of listening works for you, we are here.Our trained volunteers can offer you someone to talk to – a listening ear, a friendly voice and a chance to talk openly about whatever’s on your mind.We also offer signposting to useful resourcesany specic issues come up and information about other support out there and how to get it.So,you are a care leaver, or know a care leaver who might benefit, please remember Listening Works is here for you and not just for Christmas. Please get in touch.David Holmes CBE, chief executive, Family Action.Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, online grooming crimes in Scotland were more than  per cent higher when children were not at school compared with the same months last year.The NSPCC has been calling for legislation to protect children from grooming, abuse and harmful content online, since . After years of the charity campaigning, on December , the UK Government announced the framework for a future Online Harms Bill that has the potential to provide much greater protection for children when they use the internet.This is a landmark moment – a major step towards legislation that can make an enforceable legal duty of care on tech companies a reality. For too long children have been exposed to disgraceful abuse and harm online.Social media companies will have a duty to protect young users from child abuse and harmful content online and face fines of up to £ million or  per cent of their global turnoverthey fail.But that doesn’t mean that the work we do stops now. For instance, the proposals fall short of ensuring criminal sanctions against named directors whose companies fail to uphold their duty of care.Child protection and children’s voices must remain front and centre of regulatory requirements. We have set out six tests for robust regulation – including action to tackle both online sexual abuse and harmful content and a regulator with the power to investigate and hold tech firms to account with criminal and financial sanctions.Failing to pass any of the six tests will mean that future generations of children will pay with serious avoidable harm and sexual abuse.We will now be closely scrutinising the proposals against those tests. Above all, legislation must ensure Ofcom has the power and resources to enforce the duty of care and be able to identy and then take appropriate action against tech firms that fail.For more information, search ‘NSPCC six tests’.Joanna Barrett, policy and public affairs manager, NSPCC Scotland.

story: But what are the origins of Boxing Day and why do we celebrate it There are conflicting theories on the origins of the December  holiday ndash but it has nothing to do with the sparring sport of its namesakeOxford Dictionary claims that the day originated in the mid-th century of giving tradespeople boxes of gts the day after Christmas.According to that theory, wealthy residents would allow servants to visit their families after their efforts on Christmas Day ndash and would give them a lsquoChristmas Boxrsquo.In the rest of the UK, Boxing Day has been a bank holiday since  ndash however Scotland has only observed it since .Sweetie Scone DayIn parts of Scotland, Boxing Day was known as lsquoSweetie Scone Dayrsquo.According to Rampant Scotland, lsquosweetie sconesrsquo containing dried fruit and spices would be given by lords and ladies to hardworking staff and those less well off.How are you celebrating Boxing Day this year  Let us know in the comments or on social media.

title: emma-salisbury-releases-second-ds-kevin-coupland-book-2020
story: Emma Salisbury set herself the challenge of writing two more books in her DS Kevin Coupland series this year, rather than her usual one.Sticks and Stones was published in April and she has now released the seventh book in the series, When Darkness Falls.In the novel, set in Salford, where Emma was born, the body of a teenage girl is found two days after she is reported missing.A discussion with the pathologist reveals that another girl was found in similar circumstances.DS Coupland looks into the earlier case and finds that outdated views and social stereotyping have thwarted the investigation from the beginning.Alongside acting DS Chris Ashcroft, he lts the lid on a world where victims are defined by their postcode, and where certain crimes are written off as lestyle choices.However, beneath a layer of public indference lies a world far darker than Coupland thought possible and, just when he thinks he is getting closer to the perpetrators, a child goes missing and blows everything he thought he had discovered out of the water.And on top of all this, a couple of characters from previous novels have been brought back.Emma told the Courier she had always wonderedshe would be able to produce double her usual workload.She admitted that during lockdown she struggled to ldquomake sense of what was going on, having been forced to stay away from her family and friends, and writing her new book was a form of therapy.Emma had debated whether to mention coronavirus and lockdown in her latest story but, as she wanted her book to be as realistic as possible, she opted to refer to the situation of recent months.She said: ldquoHopefully readers like the book ndash itrsquos what they want and the feedback will be that itrsquos challenged their perspective on some things.ldquoBashing away with the book certainly helped me make sense of all that is going on right now.ldquoItrsquos been a very productive year but now Irsquom going to enjoy Christmas with my family.Askedthis would be the last book in her Coupland series, Emma said that fans would never forgive hershe were to end it now!Coupland has gained many fans over the years, with electronic versions of the series being downloaded more than , times and Emma receiving messages from readers every day.Next year, Emma plans to start work on a screenplay, believing there is demand for a Coupland TV show.She added that some fans imagined actor Tom Hardy as her famous detective.When Darkness Falls is available on Amazon.

title: bonnie-prince-charlie-horseback-statue-hopes-blindwells
story: The Battle of Prestonpans Trust is looking into creating the first equestrian statue of the Jacobite hero in his home country, overlooking the site of his most famous victory.The trust has been in talks with developers who are building the new town of Blindwells in East Lothian, which lies east of Prestonpans and on part of the site of the famous battle of .And as detailed plans for the new town layout were unveiled , the trust revealed it hoped to have a centre dedicated to the famous battle open in the town by .Plans to secure funding for the centre, which is expected to be in the town, begin next year and the trust has revealed it hopes to sponsor the equestrian statue as part of its efforts.A spokesperson for the trust said: ldquoThe centre has the potential with the support already promised from VisitScotland to bring many thousands of visitors to the economic benefit of the new community and to provide an important destination for myriad school groups.ldquoIt will also ensure signicant sharing of the extraordinary cultural legacy of the princersquos victory in both English and Gaelic.ldquo[Applicants] Hargreavesrsquo plans and the potential they can deliver for our community and our heritage have the trustrsquos deliberate support. They demonstrate precisely the wisdom necessary to conserve and interpret the nationrsquos heritage that is required as society addresses its evolving needs.ldquoWe are, for the record, also ambitious to sponsor Scotlandrsquos first equestrian statue of Bonnie Prince Charlie.Currently the only equestrian statue of Bonnie Prince Charlie is situated at Cathedral Green, Derby, which was the furthest point south the prince reached in his bid to restore a Stuart to the throne.The Blindwells project saw public consultations held online this month after detailed plans for the layout of the new town were released.Hargreaves set out a proposal for , houses, along with a town centre which will be created around a body of water named The Princersquos Loch in the north of the site.Following the public consultation, detailed planning applications are expected to be submitted to the council.

title: winton-estate-features-new-book-celebrating-trees
story: Author Vicky Allan and photographer Anna Deacon, whose book For The Love Of Trees gathered stories told by tree lovers, joined Sir Francis Ogilvy, who runs the Winton Estate, on a walk through the groundsrsquo woodlands, near Pencaitland.Sir Francis said: ldquoI was asked about the relevance of trees to a family estate where tree-planting and woodland management span centuries.ldquoAs a land agent and amateur forester, I relate easily with the passion for trees that jumps out from the [bookrsquos] pages.ldquoNow that I can see the whole book and the extraordinary collection of contributions ndash particularly since they were gathered during the Covid lockdown ndash I am filled with a desire for a wider debate of the contribution from trees and how we go forward from here.The book was produced by Vicky and Anna, who both live in Edinburgh, during lockdown and reflects the connection with nature that was nurtured by many people during this time.A spokesperson from its publisher, Black  White Publishing, said: ldquoAt a time when humanityrsquos relationship with nature is under serious examination and renewed reflection and when the worldwide carbon footprint spirals dangerously upward, trees are an increasingly important and essential part of our survival on Planet Earth.Sir Francis said: ldquoWe are witnessing extraordinary times. The facts about our environment and the effects, both positive and negative, surrounding trees around the world are well documented.ldquoHuge emphasis is placed now on tree planting, assuming that it can be done at the wave of a politicianrsquos wand.ldquoWhen planted, a tree may be the size of a ruler ndash much smaller and arguably more tender than a baby.ldquoThe trees that provide the grandeur and benefits to both the environment and to our wellbeing all take care and continuous investment throughout the le of the tree.ldquoThe economics of growing trees is a vital element to any follow-on discussion for how we develop an articulated lsquolove of treesrsquo into a sustainable programme.Sir Francis, who owns Haddington-based chartered surveyors, estate agents and architects Ogilvy Chalmers, added: ldquoIn  years of being involved in estate forestry in Scotland and England, I have yet to find an example of it being done profitably ndash notwithstanding public perception. For erse woodlands ndash typically found on country estates ndash their management is an annual expense.ldquoMy forestry lecturer extolled the merits of multi-purpose forestry: species ersity timber quality landscape shelter for farming and habitat for wildle.ldquoWe desperately need a holistic understanding of the benefits of trees and how to provide these as economically and widespread as possible.ldquoThere is plenty of room for long-term thinking and policy-making that shows we have listened to those who articulate so well the merits of trees.ldquoThat way, perhaps, future generations can say we listened and we acted ndash maybe late, but still in time.

title: elphinstone-primary-school-pinkie-st-peters-nursery-closed
story: A shortage of staff as a result of the positive Covid- cases at Elphinstone Primary and at the nursery at Pinkie St Peters have resulted in their closure ndash although the school at Pinkie St Peters remains open, while pupils at Elphinstone Primary will learn remotely for the final two days of term.A message sent to parents and carers at Elphinstone Primary yesterdaysaid: "Someone from Elphinstone Primary School has tested positive for Covid-. This has resulted in a number of people who had been in close and sustained contact with this inidual being asked to self-isolate as a precaution."Unfortunately, we will not have enough teaching staff in school for the remaining two days of term and there are no available supply teachers who are able to come to the school."As a result, we have taken the very dficult decision that all pupils will need to move to remote learning for the final two days of term ndash Monday and Tuesday."This means that your child will not be able to attend school in person on Monday and Tuesday and will need to work from home instead."We appreciate that this decision will be frustrating and inconvenient and we are having to move quickly on completion of the contact tracing process following this recent confirmed case. However, under these very dficult circumstances, we believe this decision is the only option open to us and is in the interests of everyonersquos health and safety."We had developed remote blended as a contingency ahead of the re-opening of our schools in August and will now be calling upon these arrangements. This of course follows our experience of delivering remote learning during the spring summer term."We want to reassure parents that appropriate tasks and assignments will be readily available for pupils on Monday and Tuesday via Google Classroom."Since the start of this pandemic, our school community has taken every precaution possible to limit the transmission of Covid-. We are all hugely proud of the work of all staff , children and the support of parents under extremely dficult and unprecedented circumstances. This has enabled us to maintain high-quality learning and teaching since the reopening of the school in August."However, this situation highlights that Covid- continues to present a signicant risk. It is important that everyone around the country continues to follow the really important national public health advice, including the importance of observing lsquoFACTSrsquo ndash including wearing face coverings where recommended, avoiding crowded areas, cleaning hands, two-metres physical distancing and self-isolatingsymptoms develop."Meanwhile, an East Lothian Council spokesperson said of the case at Pinkie St Peters nursery: "We were notied of someone from Pinkie St Peters Primary School Nursery who has tested positive for Covid-."A number of people who had been in close and sustained contact with this inidual are being asked to self-isolate as a precaution."Unfortunately, there are not enough teaching staff in the nursery for the remaining two days of term and there are no available supply teachers who are able to come to the nursery."Consequently we are having to close the Nursery on Monday and Tuesday."However, parents and carers at all other schools in East Lothian have received the following message: "Following public health advice, the Scottish Government advises schools should remain OPEN until the end of term."Public health has also confirmed our schools and early learning and childcare settings have, and should continue with, the effective measures already in place."We understand that some parents have been in touch to say they will keep their child at home. If you intend to keep your child at home, please inform your school as you normally would."On Tuesday, we will update parents and carers about arrangements for the start of the new term in January ."First Minister Nicola Sturgeon previously announced on Saturday that only the children of keyworkers and the most vulnerable wouldto school as originally planned on January , with school not starting for all other pupils until January  and remote learning taking place until at least January .

story: The delay, put in place to suppress the spread of Covid-, will be introduced to take account of public health advice.Schools in East Lothian had initially been due toon January , but in an title: tims-tales-jamie-elder-tree
story: But the sun wis dying fast, and the heavens were beginning tae tak their turn tae shine in the winter nichtrsquos sky. Soon Jamie foond himsel in dairkness, wi naethin but a sliver orsquo the moon and the stars tae guide his way.It wis sae dairk, and he wis sae tired, that he wandered aff his path. There wis nae hoose tae get directions and he couldnae even see the silhouette orsquo the Lammermuirs tae give him a sense orsquo direction. He wis lost. But mair than that, he realised he wis gettin gye cauld, andhe didnae find shelter soon he may be deid afore the year wis.He minded his faitherrsquos sayin ldquowhen a deadly wind blaws, seek yer beild be it a hame or bush. There wis nae windae licht tae be seen, sae Jamie looked in the dairkness for a bush.He fouod an elder tree, grawin alane. It wis all bent owre by years of defyin the wind. He decided tae coorie in under its branches, at least fir a wee while tae gie him some respite frae the biting wind.Despite the fact the branches were bare, they were woven thegither, makin a wee den which gaed shelter. It wis just in time, fir the windrsquos mood worsened, and the blawing became a ragin blizzard. Jamie lay under the elderrsquos branches and tucked in his jaicket and pursquod doon his bonnet. He sae wanted tae be hame, but he kent the storm noo wanted his le, and this tree wis his only protection frae it.He closed his een, and sichtrsquos of hame flickered in his mind. He didnae ken where he wis but he kent he couldnae be that far frae hame. His bairns and his beloved Heather wud be sair worried aboot him. He willnae be wi them noo fir the bells. It made him want tae risk venturing oot, but then the tree seemed tae whisper tae him: ldquoBide here son, Irsquoll keep ye safe. Irsquove seen mony storms, they mak lang nichts, but they ay pass.Jamie understood.It wis indeed a lang nicht but the elder kept the frozen claws orsquo the blizzard awa frae Jamie, as he lay under its branches, catching wee bits of sleep. Finally the morn arrived as the sun rose frae the sea, and spread its golden rays across the land. Jamie pursquod himself up, hud a wee shoogle tae clear the snaw frae his claes and looked aroond. The cauld sunshine streaked ower the snaw-covered land, makin it sparkle.ldquoOch, I dinnae believe it! he said tae himself, as he recognised exactly where he wis. The tree hud bin richt the storm hud passed and he was alive, although cauld and noo very hungry.He set aff hame, but stopped fir a moment tae turn roond an look at the elder tree. Its bare branches hud been sculpted by the wind, and wi the backgroond orsquo snaw, it looked like a figure bent ower an image orsquo an auld wummin makin a bield fir her bairn.ldquoThank ye, he said tae the tree.Jamie arrived hame afore noon on New Yearrsquos Day. He wis the first footer fir his ain hoose. He warmed himsel by the hearth and wi the welcome and love orsquo his bairns and dear we. He hud a tale tae tell of how an elder tree saved his le. And tell it he did, sae lang ater this the elder became kent in the neighbourhood as lsquoJamiersquos Treersquo.And frae that day, Jamie wud often tak a wee detour oan his travels tae visit the tree. title: zans-wildlife-diary-arrival-waxwings-east-lothian-winter
story: When I was younger, I could spend hours standing at the window watching the snow fall. I was always mesmerised by how quickly the rough landscape changed into a white wonderland like from the most beautul fairy tale. This was also the time that I associated with countless presents . Who does not like them !Now I still adore winter but for dferent reasons, namely for its wildle visitors to the country. Last month, I introduced you to one of them ndash the short-eared owl ndash and now it is time I presented my favourite winter migrant: the Bohemian waxwing.The sight of a waxwing can brighten up any winter day, regardless of how keen on birding you are. Two years ago, I was privileged to spend a fantastic afternoon with these birds.It was a chilling but sunny day. As my dad, who is a nature lover, was visiting me for Christmas, I took the opportunity to take him on a trip to Aberlady. This place is always rich in all sorts of wildle. I also knew that some waxwing sightings had been recorded earlier that week.As soon as we arrived, I spotted a rather big flock of birds that briefly circulated above our heads before disappearing towards the reserve. Everything happened so fast that I did not have enough time to pick up my binoculars for a closer look at the birds.We rushed towards a copse of rowan trees, where I knew the waxwings would most likely congregate. As we were coming closer, I could recognise the merry trill that these stunning birds make as they were happily feeding on berries. You may remember from my previous articles how careful I am when it comes to approaching wildle. This time was no dferent we took our time watching the waxwings from a distance, letting them get used to our presence. This is a great technique to signal to wildle that we are no threat to them.Suddenly, the flock was spooked by a dog and raised high in the sky for a split second before landing above our heads. My dad and I gave each other a knowing grin and started admiring the beautul creatures sitting merely a couple of metres away from us. This was an unusual moment to me as a wildle photographer: the birds were so close that my lens was too big to capture the scene! But that picture of waxwings having a feast right above me will stay in my memory for a long time.Waxwings are often mistaken for common starlings. These two species are similar in size and, to an extent, profile.However,you look closely, you should spot the peach-brown colouring of waxwingsrsquo plumage. An even closer look will reveal the real charm and beauty that these birds possess: the enlivening neutral base colours are accompanied by splashes of white and red in the wings and a strong yellow band at the base of the tail. The head is crowned by a distinctive crest, which can be raised or lowered depending on the birdrsquos mood. Adding to their appeal is the prominent black mask on their eyes.Waxwings are gregarious birds, who can form large flocks consisting of hundreds of iniduals. They breed in boreal forest that extends from Scandinavia through Russia and across to the Pacic coast.Waxwings are a forgiving subject to photograph they do not encounter humans within their breeding habitats, therefore are approachable on their winter grounds, providing a great opportunity to capture them feeding on colourful berry trees.Waxwings make a loud but cheerful trill as they scour the landscape looking for fruit.Berries are incredibly important for waxwings in the winter. These birds can eat up to twice their body weight, which makes around -, berries a day!Their diet changes during their breeding season as the birds switch to feeding on mosquitoes and midges.Our native rowan is their favoured tree, but they will happily feed on hawthorn, cotoneaster and rosehips as well as dried fruit.If waxwings are in the area and you do not have berries, they can be attracted into gardens using apple halves hung from a tree. It is common to spot waxwings in such ordinary places as supermarket car parks, as they often have ornamental shrubs with berries.This was my first year writing Zanrsquos Wildle Diary and I have greatly enjoyed sharing my stories and experiences with you. I hope you all had fun reading my column!If you have enjoyed my pictures this year and would like to see more, I now have Wildle Calendars  for sale. Get in touch for more details.I would like to wish you all a very merry Christmas and a happy New Year when it comes!zanslensfacebook zanslens instagram zans_lens twitter zans_lens

story: NHS Lothian announced the venues yesterday , saying all three were capable of providing thousands of vaccinations at a time.The next phase of the vaccination programme, known as Wave , is shorty expected to begin across Scotland to vaccinate people aged -, followed by those aged - and -, and then adults with risk factors over the age of .NHS Lothian has been working with councils, health and social care partnerships, and other partners to ensure the sites are ready when the roll-out begins, which is expected in February.Edinburgh International Conference Centreand The Pyramids Business Parkin West Lothian have been agreed as two of the centres, and at Queen Margaret University details are being finalised.A number of local supplementary centres are also being set up by the four health and social care partnerships across the Lothian healthboard area to supplement the bigger venues.David Small, director of primary care and transformation at NHS Lothian, who is leading the programme, said he was delighted that three large-scale venues had been agreed.He said: ldquoThis is the biggest mass vaccination programme undertaken. It is a massive task and even though all of the teams are working at speed, we know we need to make sure we get the delivery right, first time.ldquoThere are a lot of challenges involved across the project, but we are meeting each one and we are delighted that these three venues are finalised.ldquoWe still have a number of other options to consider and explore, but this is a milestone.ldquoIt means we can begin work in the new year while we continue planning the smaller centres which will supplement the bigger venues.Sir Paul Grice, principal of Queen Margarey University, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be able to play this part in the national effort to run the biggest mass vaccination programme ever undertaken.ldquoI am very grateful for the efforts of staff across the university to facilitate this, and to East Lothian Council for its support in putting the arrangements in place to allow it to happen.At the Musselburgh-based university, a drive-through vaccination centre is being planned that would have about  stations and be able to vaccinate , people a week.It is expected that a section of the universitys car park will be used for this.Plans are being developed to create a walk-through centre at the EICC which would be capable of vaccinating , a week at about  stations.A similar walk-through centre is expected to be set up in PBP, which could provide , vaccinations every week using about  stations.People will be contacted by the NHS when they are eligible for a vaccination appointment.People should not contact the venues directly as they would not hold any of the relevant information.This new phase will be followed in the spring by the roll-out of Wave , which will also target inidual age groups, starting with those aged -, then -, - and then followed by the rest of the population.

story: Tracey Sadek-Moore decided to challenge herself during lockdown and after giving birth to her second son, Zayn, earlier this year.The East Linton mum pledged to run a total of  kilometresover title: motoring-seven-tips-help-keep-car-clean-winter
story: Keeping a car clean during the winter months might seem like an impossibility at times, and there can be temptation not to bother giving your car a good scrub until the temperatures start to warm up again.But colder weather means gritted roads - and you dont want to leave this salt on your car for extended periods of time, as it can lead to corrosion over the years.Soyoure looking to keep your car in the best state over winter, here are the tips we recommend following.... Get a pressure washerWhile you might think a regular hose will do the job just fine,youre able to, we recommend getting a pressure washer to clean your car. These are able to offer more power when cleaning - especially when it comes to areas such as the wheel arches. Good pressure washers are available for under pound, and while this might seem a bit pricey at first, youll soon find they come in handy for all sorts of tasks.. Dont skip the pre-washGiving your car a pre-wash is important at the best of times, but even more so in winter. Essentially, before you actually touch the car, its important to get as much of that dirt off as possible.There are ious ways you can do this - including using snowfoam, which helps to loosen dirt. But our chosen method is using whats known as an all-purpose cleaner or citrus cleaner. Its best to wet the car first, before spraying these cleaners on, which can usually be heavily diluted and still pack impressive cleaning power. Always check the instructions and dilution ratios before using.Leave the cleaner on the vehicle for around five minutes before pressure washing the dirt off - youll be surprised by how much it removes.. Use two buckets and a dedicated car shampooWhile it can be tempting to grab the mop bucket and fill it with washing up liquid, this couldnt be further from what we recommend for cleaning your car.Washing up liquid contains ingredients that are designed to strip grease from pots and pans, but on a cars paint this can degrade the finishused on a regular basis. For that reason, a dedicated car shampoo should be used, and good products can be picked up for as little as a fiver.Following this, we recommend using two buckets - one containing the car shampoo mixture and the second nothing but clean water. Well explain why shortly.. Ditch the sponge and use a wash mittFor years, a sponge has been thought of as the ultimate tool for cleaning a car, but these can actually cause damage to your car.Even after a pre-wash, there will still be dirt on your car, and when using a sponge, these dirt particles have nowhere to go - so essentially youll be rubbing grit around on the car, which could cause marks to be inflicted. Instead, use a deep pile wash mitt, which helps to sort the issue.The process goes, dunk the mitt in the car shampoo bucket, clean the area youre doing, then put in the clean water bucket, rinse, repeat.. Clean top to bottomAnother important thing to remember when cleaning your car is the method. While it can be tempting to just rub around in circles, this can cause whats known as swirls, which ruin the way your car looks.Instead, you should aim to clean in straight lines, whether thats up and down, or side to side. You should also work from top to bottom - the roof and bonnet of your car being far less likely to have dirt on them than the lower . Once youve cleaned all , rinse the vehicle thoroughly.. Lay down some protectionEspecially in winter, its important to lay down some protection on your car, which will help to repel any dirt and also make future washing cleaner.While you can use a dedicated spray wax or paste wax for this, one of the quickest ways of doing this is to use a spray wax that you apply while the vehicle is wet after washing it. Spray this on the clean wet , before rinsing off straight away - youll immediately be able to tell the dference.. Dry off the carOnce youve rinsed off your car, it can be tempting to just leave it, but we always recommend drying off your vehicle - whether or not youve opted for step six.Use a microfibre towel for drying your car, which is able to soak up an impressive amount of water. If you just leave the water on your car to let it air-dry, it can leave water spots and also make it look a smeary mess.

In the last few days of any year theres always that urge to tot things up, to take a measure of the  months youve just gone through and what you have ndash or more likely have not ndash achieved. Another year and you still havent travelled the world written that novel did your bit to end climate change.At the fag end of this yellow-stained, miserable year, I think its fair to suggest thatyou are feeling fretful about what you havent done, then you really need to give yourself a break. Getting through this year is achievement enough, quite frankly.Far too many people havent, after all.Travel the world  Fat chance this year. Write a novel  Reading one seems pretty good going to me in a year when anxiety and doom-scrolling have been eating up so much time.No doubt, right now, there is someone working away on the novel that will nail the smeary, scary tedium of . It wont be me, but Id be happy to read it when its published.The truth is, this year we should be reassessing what our measure of achievement is anyway. If youve managed to work from home without burning out, give yourself a clap on the back. If youve been furloughed and kept yourself together, thats great. If youve been a key worker, whether in the NHS or in the local takeaway, we salute you.This year what have I managed to do  Did a bit of work, read nearly  books , watched a few movies, listened to a lot of radio, managed an hour or two not seething about the inadequacies of Boris Johnson and, oh yes, climbed Dumyat in the Ochils.That was a few months back. My mate whos a proper hillwalker took me up, which was kind of him. Admittedly, he spent most of the not-very-taxing walk moaning that it wasnt a proper hill, but I didnt mind.Ive been living close to Dumyat for most of the  years Ive lived in Scotland , and Ive kept meaning to climb up to the top, survey the Forth valley, which, after all, is the landscape for most of my adult le. But I never had. In that brief window this summer when we could all go out and do things , I finally did.Yes, it was an easy enough walk. But that didnt matter. There was still a sense of achievement and of a task completed. Not a task that mattered or that made a dference to anyone . But it made a dference to me.This has been a year for celebrating small victories. Its possible that the year ahead will be much the same. So, cherish the ones you have managed whatever they may be.

title: Steve Clarke  Bob Dylan  Dolly Parton  Here s the alternative  and real  honours list for 2020
story: The EastEnders actor spoke for many when he said the Covid catastrophe had exposed certain politiciansrsquo unfitness for office. ldquoWe must learn now that the people who went to Eton canrsquot run this country, he declared. ldquoWe need some working class people, people who have lived a real le, that are in touch with whatrsquos going on, to come to the front now and start getting involved with how this countryrsquos run. Handily for the star of Run for Your We, the Scottish Parliament elections take place next May. We know his family tree includes William the Conqueror and Henry III. Surely there must be a Scottish granny lurking somewhere in the branches She made history as the first woman and the first BAME person to become vice president-elect of the US, erased the pain of Hillary, annoyed the bejeezus out of Donald Trump, and did it all while rocking a white trouser suit like Travolta. Both she and -year-old president-elect Joe Biden were named Timersquos Person of the Year. So far, the pair have run their three-legged race well. The real marathon begins after the inauguration on January .: FM apologises for breaching Covid rulesLike Archie Gemmill heading for the Dutch goal, the Scotland manager juked round decades of humiliation, nutmegged the national tendency to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory, and took Scotland to its first major tournament in  years. He was an example to politicians everywhere of getting the job done, and he did so in a decidedly Scottish, understated way, a personality trail blazed by Andy Murray, Jock Stein and many another sporting great.When he warned in Subterranean Homesick Blues against following leaders , Dylan must have had a vision of . With the exception of New Zealandrsquos PM Jacinda Ardern, the worldrsquos premiers tried and failed to get ahead of the virus, and some of them paid the price . The first musician to win the Nobel Prize in Literature scored a hit by selling the rights to his songs, all of which he owned, for pound million, thus confirming he always has been the smartest guy in the music industryrsquos room.The professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh has shone a light through the fog of bluster generated by politicians. Cool, clear and articulate, she is an example to anyone who needs to communicate a message. Her florist has played a blinder, too, with prof Bauldrsquos ldquomedia cupboard never short of a nice vase of blooms.It had become an accepted fact of modern le that community wasnrsquot what it used to be , and that you and your neighbours were destined to be, at best, strangers on nodding terms. The pandemic changed that. We shopped for others, had socially distanced alfresco chats, and generally felt grateful for the people around us. Even her at number .It is not often a Labour MSP, or any MSP, finds themselves the subject of headlines in the New York Times. But on November ,  the Gray Lady reported that Scotland had become ldquothe first country in the world to make period products freely available to all who need them. After a four year campaign, Scottish Labourrsquos health spokesperson smashed taboos along the way with the Period Products Act. As Lennon said: ldquoThere has been a massive change in the way that periods are discussed in public le. A few years ago there had never been an open discussion of menstruation in the Holyrood chamber and now it is mainstream.The first lockdown began with Matt Hancock, Englandrsquos Health Secretary, telling footballers to lead by example and take a pay cut. Then along came a lad of  in a Man United shirt and showed Mr Hancock and the rest of the Cabinet how politics could and should be done. Marcus Rashford, the son of a single mother who worked full time yet couldnrsquot always afford to put food on the table, reckoned poor children going hungry in st century Britain was just plain wrong. His campaign to feed them year round manoeuvred the UK Government into a position where it could not say no. As one banner put it: ldquoRashford , Boris .How magnicent is the First Lady of country music  Let us count some of the ways. Besides continuing a career in which she has sold hundreds of millions of records, the now -year-old showed she had a keen eye for science and a heart for philanthropy when it was revealed she had given  million to the search for a Covid- vaccines. The product she had backed was among the successful ones. She may have famously said of herself that, ldquoIt takes a lot of money to look this cheap, but Miss Parton is four feet nine inches of sheer class.: Issue of the Day - Dolly PartonThe author took more than a decade to produce his debut novel, Shuggie Bain, but it arrived like a benign asteroid trailing showers of praise. Our own Teddy Jamieson described it as ldquoa fierce yet tender account of poverty, addiction and queerness in s Glasgow. Sighthill-born Stuart was only the second Scot to win the Booker after James Kelman with How Late it Was, How Late, in . While both were written in an authentic Scottish urban dialect, only Kelmanrsquos masterpiece had the literary establishment clutching its pearls in astonishment, bordering on outrage, that a working class voice was victorious. What a dference  years had made.: Douglas Stuart, The Herald Magazine interviewOur columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: opinion-brian-beacoms-week-priti-patel
story: As for the grilling Irsquove been getting about schools re-opening  I canrsquot tell you about all pupils because, obviously, schools operate dferently across the country. And I certainly canrsquot tell Nicola what to do. I fear she could be a bigger bully than me. . Donrsquot give me that disdainful look.Yes, the November enquiry deemed Irsquod breached the ministerial code again. But then ministerial codes are like the Enigma. Theyrsquore there to be broken! At least the last time I broke ministerial protocol I was clever enough to be tanking a lovely pound, an hour. I know there was an alleged conflict of interests Home Secretary takes cash from global communications firm that supplies products and services to the UK Government. But that wasnrsquot the case at all. There is no conflict for me when cash is involved. And the media love to take my comments out of context. Like the time I said that the economic impact of a no-deal Brexit on the Republic of Ireland could encourage the EU to drop the backstop.Well, some people actually took that at face value. And just because in one interview I repeatedly confused lsquocounter-terrorismrsquo with lsquoterrorismrsquo some label me lsquoPriti Vacant.rsquo Easy mistake to make, Mister! Sure, critics like to say I only got into politics because Dave had me fast-tracked into a safe seat, to widen the party demographic. Well, that may be true, but Irsquove always been an opportunist.They forget I was happy to work for a PR company with a contract with British American Tobacco and a remit to convince African kids to start puffinrsquo like lab beagles. I wasnrsquot vague either at the time when I was up for capital punishment, and down on the idea of same-sex marriages.Irsquove kicked out at Windrush and Extinction Rebellion. And I was as clear as the space between Dominic Raabrsquos ears when I once said I wasnrsquot strictly in favour of the rule of law ndash which I suppose as Home Secretary is a bit like Craig Revel Horwood saying itrsquos ok for Strictly contestants to make up the moves as they go along. But we need a bit of freestyle thinking in this world donrsquot we Sure, Theresa resigned me as International Development Secretary after the time I holidayed in Isreal and instead of taking little Freddie to the waterparks in Eilat I took  off-the-book meetings with dignitaries such as Benjamin Netanyahu. But you can have a lot of fun in the Golan Heights too you know. But Irsquom back, under Boris, so to speak. And as protected as a white tiger. story: But increasing alarm over not one, but two, highly contagious iant strains of the new coronavirus circulating in the UK has changed that.Now I find it dficult to imagine that we are facing anything  as we prepare to enter the new year.If the experience of South Africa and south-east England is anything to go by, softer circuit break restrictions will not be enough.We may even need something tougher than we had in March.A briefing by scientists on the UKrsquos NERVTAGnoted that the UK iant ldquohas demonstrated exponential growth during a period when national lockdown measures were in place.: % of Covid infections in Scotland linked to UK iant strainContaining the spread of this strain will require extremely high compliance with stay-at-home rules and self-isolation in particular - something which has been woeful in the UK until now.In France, anyone leaving their homes during lockdown must complete attestationforms stating their reasons for going out - for example, essential work, collecting children from schools, picking up medicines. Residents caught outside without a valid reason or straying further than the permitted kilometrefrom their property have been hit with eurofines.In Greece, citizens must text their name, address and reason for wishing to leave their house to a five-digit government number to request permission to go out.This might seem anathema to le in the UK, but can it be a coincidence that in the past few days both Nicola Sturgeonand UK Health Secretary Matt Hancockhave raised the prospect of legal enforcements for both " alt"HeraldScotland: Cases of coronavirus have been rising in the south and east of England, where the mutant strain is concentrated, but falling in other regions " class"editor-image"Cases of coronavirus have been rising in the south and east of England, where the mutant strain is concentrated, but falling in other regions We are in a perilous situation - undoubtedly the worst since the virus first arrived in the UK - and while the prospect of mass vaccination gives us hope, we have a long way to go, at least until mid-, before substantial population coverage is likely to be achieved.If these iants take hold as experts fear they could, we must think seriously about better practical and financial support to enable people to self-isolate, both in the form of of quarantine hotels and making isolation payments either more generous for the low-paid or simply easier to access .So what do we know so far about these iants which have cancelled Christmas and look set to overshadow the new year The UK iant, known as VUI  is characterised by a total of  mutations compared to the original Wuhan cluster -  of which appear to have occurred in at once.: We could have had a normal Christmas - but the time to achieve it was JulyThe leading theory for now - although investigations are ongoing - is that the iant first evolved in September in a patient, possibly in the Kent area, who was sick with the infection for a long time, maximising the opportunity for mutations.These are naturally lsquocopying errorsrsquo which occur at a molecular level as the virus replicates in its human hosts and spreads. Think of it like a -page book where every so often a couple of letters randomly switch places as new copies are rushed off the press.Occasionally one of these mutations will confer a lsquoselective advantagersquo - such as making a virus more transmissible. As a general rule in virology, however, the more infectious a virus becomes the more its lethality dwindles.For example, the original  SARS killed around  per cent of people who caught it compared to the new SARS-CoV- version, which has an estimated case-fatality rate somewhere in the region of .-% . But SARS also ran out of steam and no case has been detected anywhere in the world since .A virusrsquo only goal is to be passed on and multiply, which is better achieved by being highly contagious - but not overly deadly.It remains to be seen of course whether this will turn out to be the case for the UK iant, which is estimated to be % more transmissible and as of mid-December was accounting for around % of all new cases in London.The UK and South Africa have experienced a huge surge in cases since the beginning of DecemberThere has been a suggestion that the iant may be more infectious in children after NERVTAG member Professor Neil Ferguson told journalists that the number of cases of the new iant detected in under-s is ldquosignicantly higher ldquothan other strains, but there is currently no published evidence to demonstrate that.: If only taking back control had applied to our borders in a pandemicThe South African mutation, dubbed .YV, has been detected in two locations in Britain - in London and the north-west of England. It makes up around % of the new cases in South Africa, which is currently in the midst of its summer when the disease should have been easier to control.On Wednesday, South Africarsquos Health Minister Dr Zweli Mkhize warned that the ldquorate of spread is much faster than the first wave and we will surpass the peak of the first wave in the coming days.In Scotland positive Covid cases have been rising again since early DecemberWorryingly for the UK, Dr Mkhize has suggested the disease could actually be more lethal in young people, saying that doctors ldquoare seeing a larger proportion of younger patients with no co-morbidities presenting with critical illness.However, it is also true that young people may be getting sick because many more of them are getting infected this time around, with students and teenagers blamed for super-spreading the virus with post-exam parties.The South African iant has more mutations, three of which might affect vaccine efficacy, though this could be rectiednecessary.In the meantime, standard measures - hand-washing, social distancing, and self-isolation - remain our best defence against transmission. But compliance will be more important than ever.

title: Rosemary Goring  39 s Country Life  Let   s all hope the first signs of spring don   t have a sting in their tail
story: Gardening books advise you to clean and oil every tool before it is stored. More realistic sorts accept that most of us give at best a cursory flick of a cloth to trowels, or a trickle of three-in-one to shears and secateurs, leaving the full spa treatment to the quietest season of the year.Spring cleaning is for the house, but midwinter is the time to polish, sharpen and grease the tools yoursquove taken for granted the previous  months. As soon Alan gets the place shipshape, Irsquoll be getting on with that.The shed was the first thing we bought when we arrived at the cottage. Previously, a dilapidated wooden shack sagged near the back door. It was like a prop from Cold Comfort Farm, the door unable to open more than half a foot because so much gravel and mud had washed down the path.Within a week of moving in, it had been demolished and carted off, and from the fence by the field came the sound of hammering as a new shed was erected, just in time for Christmas. We ought to have tied a ribbon on it, because that year there was little chance of much in the way of more personal gts. Because of the slope, the shedrsquos front legs are longer than the back. It gave us a place to start gathering stuff like every other garden owner, and offered hedgehogs a safe retreat in the crawl space beneath, should they think about taking up residence.In the autumn, a neighbour took me into her beech hedge, which is so wide and high that you can stand upright in the centre. Here, among the sparrow roosts, she had installed a dinky wooden hedgehog house she had hammered together. Itrsquos the kind of property development everyone can embrace.Our local garden centre sells wicker versions, which are shaped like igloos. With a narrow entrance tunnel leading to a rounded chamber, they remind me of Maeshowe in Orkney.The roof of our hut is home to spiders, which occasionally are picked off when a robin darts inside, so swt a sortie itrsquos like a special operations mission. One hot day in our first summer here, I left the door ajar. I came back an hour later to discover wasps had begun to build bings. They were stuck to the walls like golf balls, getting larger by the minute.If only we had owned PPE in those days, wersquod have been able to swing into action immediately.As it was, it took a while to get a spray ndash kindly lent by a neighbour ndash and find a way of covering Alan top to toe. Wearing gloves, hood, and shirt buttoned to the neck, he went in looking like an international inspector investigating Chernobyl.He was back indoors before a kamikaze wasp was discovered crawling around inside his clothes, giving its all in defence of its realm. By the time Alan had ripped off and shaken out his shirt, he had been stung. The wasp, meanwhile, was even more injured, and when I finally found it on a windowsill, it had gasped its last.Now, we keep the shed door closed most of the time. Wasps are welcome to nest where, and in the past couple of years have burrowed underground beneath the birch tree and the beech hedge. Sometimes they buzz angrily as we pass, and occasionally I have been chased down the path until I am at a safe distance.On warm days, when Irsquom in the summer house, I can hear them on the walls outside, chewing at the wood and making pulp. They make a sound like a scratching fingernail. Who knew such a tiny creature could be such a noisy eater Around the winter solstice, when darkness is falling by mid-afternoon, summer is unimaginable. This year it feels particularly far off. The garden looks dank and dreary and, with its overlong grass, has an abandoned air. A friend offered his lawnmower for one last trim before winter, but by the time the rainclouds parted, everything was sodden. As a result, a trip to the shed or the summer house sounds like wading through water which, these past few weeks, is close to the truth.Irsquove been assiduously reading books that recommend what to plant to keep borders filled with colour all year round, but at the moment achieving that is a distant dream. Walking around Hoolet, I take notes of how people make their front gardens look more inviting. Looking at our own, I wonder how it is that when yoursquore out in the countryside, the tangle of dying undergrowth and grass is beautul, yet our better-tended patch looks unkempt and sorry for itself Not all is gloom. Shoots of spring bulbs are coming through. The first snowdrop has appeared, its flower dangling like a pearl earring, solitary and brave. Nearby, a couple of milky hellebores brighten up the flowerbed. One was given to us by a friend instead of a Christmas card last year, and we think of her whenever we pass.Before New Year arrives I will make a list of the plants in the garden, and who gave them to us. Itrsquos like a Whorsquos Who of Hoolet, from shrubs and flowers to bulbs and even ndash at the heart of them all ndash a young tree, seeded from a magnicent copper beech in the farmhouse across the green. Still no more than a sapling, it is finding its feet or, as a real gardener would say, putting down roots.In that sense, itrsquos no dferent from us. The other evening, as we were driving out of the village, a barn owl flew out of the hedgerow, uplit by our headlights as it flapped towards the fields. It is either the same bird, or related to the one photographed in the summer, patrolling the edge of Hoolet.I look forward to the owls ing to our chimney, where we first heard them calling to each other.

title: coronavirus-virus-turned-lives-upside
story: On December , Dr Li Wenliang, messaged fellow medics via chat group Weibo warning them to wear protective clothing in order to avoid infection.Four days later, the -year-old was summoned to the Public Security Bureau where he was ordered to sign a letter admitting to ldquomaking  comments that had ldquoseverely disturbed the social order.In a tragic twist, this whistleblower would go on to contract the virus himself within weeks and in February, he died.On December , the World Health Organisationrsquos Country Office was notied of a pneumonia ldquoof an unknown cause emerging in the city of Wuhan.There were more than  patients -  of whom were severely ill - and a number of them were seafood dealers or vendors with links to the Huanan wet market.: Oxford vaccine tipped to be approved within daysExactly when and where this new form of coronavirus emerged has never been pinpointed but a study by Hard Medical School would later observe that as far back as September and October  there had been a ldquodramatic increase in traffic to Wuhanrsquos major hospitals and a spike in queries on Chinese internet for ldquocertain symptoms that would later be determined as closely associated with the novel coronavirus.The first the world knew of a mysterious new disease that would soon come to engulf it, however, was when WHO issued an alert via its social media on January , describing fever, breathing dficulties and lesions in the lung. Crucially, at that point, there was not believed to be any human-to-human transmission.By January , Chinese scientists had published the genetic sequence for the virus, paving the way to the rapid development of vaccines.Two days later the WHO reported ldquolimited human-to-human transmission and a ldquorisk of a possible wider outbreak.That same day, the first case of the virus outside of China - in a -year-old Wuhan resident on holiday in Thailand - was confirmed.On January , China imposed a ban on travel to and from Wuhan, but by then an estimated five million people had already poured out all over South-East to celebrate Chinese New Year and - in any case - the virus had long since seeped into Europe.China imposed temperature checks and travel bans in January Although Europersquos first confirmed case was reported in France on January , in an inidual recently ed from China, it would later emerge that a swab from a pneumonia patient treated at a Paris hospital on December  - and retrospectively analysed for Covid - had tested positive.In Italy sewage water collected in Milan and Turin on December  would reveal genetic traces of the virus, as did waste water collected in mid-January in Barcelona.By the end of January there were , total confirmed cases worldwide, including in  countries outside of China, and the WHO declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern.As the UK exited the EU on January , two Chinese nationals - a York University student and one of their family members - were under quarantine at a Newcastle hospital after falling ill with the virus, while  British citizens who had been stranded in Wuhan landed at RAF Brize Norton to begin  days of self-isolation.Steve Walsh became known as a coronavirus superspreader after a trip to SingaporeIt marked the beginning of the end of normality in Britain. Within days a businessman from Hove, Steve Walsh, would become the first British national diagnosed with Covid in the UK after attending a conference in Singapore.He is also believed to have infected at least  others - including two British GPs - when he stopped off at a French ski resort on his way home.Genomic testing would later show that the virus arrived and began circulating in Scotland in February, mainly as a result of cases imported from Europe and prior to an outbreak linked to a Nike conference held at Edinburghrsquos Hilton Carlton on February - where one infected delegate passed the virus on to  others - eight of them Scotland residents.The first confirmed case in Scotland came on March , however, in a Tayside resident who had recently ed from northern Italy, where infections were already raging out of control.On March , Italy became the first European nation to impose a then-unprecedented nationwide lockdown, closing shops, schools, bars, and restaurants, ordering the public to stay at home, and forbidding travel between regions.: After Covid, is it time to reform Scotlands care sector - andso, how In the UK, where the first confirmed Covid death - a patient in her s at Royal Berkshire hospital - had been reported on March , the deteriorating situation on the Continentwas seen as an omen for what was to come.Brits responded by panic buying. By March , UK supermarkets were rationing toilet paper, dried pasta and tinned goods to prevent shoppers stockpiling.On March , the Republic of Ireland closed schools, colleges, universities and public facilities within  hours of the countryrsquos first confirmed Covid death.The following day, Scotland confirmed its own first Covid death - in an elderly hospital patient treated in Lothian - and care homes were advised to close except to ldquoessential visits.At that point, nine cases were being reported in Scotlandrsquos care homes by the end of April there would be nearly , Covid deaths among care home residents.On March , all non-urgent elective procedures were suspended as NHS Scotland was placed on an emergency footing amid fears over an influx of Covid admissions.A week later, Scotlandrsquos schools were closed and pubs, nightclubs and restaurants UK-wide were ordered to close on March , with a furlough scheme introduced in a bid to protect jobs.On March  - with  confirmed cases in Scotland and Covid hospital admissions averaging  per day - the UK was finally plunged into lockdown.Hospital admissions would go on to peak in Scotland at  in a single day on April  .April also saw the departure of Scotlandrsquos chief medical officer, Dr Catherine Calderwood, who was forced to resign after it emerged she had twice travelled from Edinburgh to her second home in Earlsferry, Fe, in breach of guidance to remain in your local area and avoid non-essential travel.ldquoPeople across Scotland know what they need to do to reduce the spread of this virus and that means they must have complete trust in those who give them advice, said Dr Calderwood.The scandal coincided on April  with Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who had been self-isolating with coronavirus at Downing Street, being admitted to hospital.Prime Minister Boris Johnson on steps of Number  days before he was admitted to hospital The following day, with his condition deteriorating, the -year-old PM - whose fiancee Carrie Symonds was weeks away from giving birth to the couplersquos first child - was transferred into intensive care. His condition was said to have been so grave at the time that he had only a - chance of surviving.He recovered, however, and was discharged from hospital six days later, praising two nurses - ldquoJenny from New Zealand and Luis from Portugal - who stood by his bedside for  hours at the most critical time.By April , alarm was mounting over the situation in Scotlandrsquos care homes after a string of outbreaks claimed the lives of elderly residents at premises in Dumbarton, North Lanarkshire and Tranent.: Mutant strains mean we must rethink lockdown, self-isolation, and the danger of the pandemicScottish Care said a survey of its members found that around half of care homes in Scotland had at least one suspected case of coronavirus at the time.The Scottish Government and Care Inspectorate came under pressure to make the data publicly available amid criticism of PPE shortages and lack of testing for care home staff and residents.National Records of Scotland data would go on to show that over  weeks, from March , there were , deaths from all causes in Scotlandrsquos care homes - nearly twice as many as would normally occur at the same time of year.On April , Dr Gregor Smith - who replaced Dr Calderwood as interim CMO - warned that the number of people in Scotland being referred for cancer tests by their GP had fallen by % in the first weeks of lockdown, as he urged people not to ignore symptoms. Attendance at AE departments had also more than halved.On April , Scotland surpassed  Covid deaths for the first time, as  deaths were confirmed in a single day among people who had tested positive for the infection - taking the total to ,.May marked the beginning of the end for the UK lockdown, as the first wave slowed.On May , England began allowing people unlimited outdoor exercise and to meet up in a public place with one person from another household.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon went on to unveil Scotlandrsquos own four-phase ldquoroadmap out of lockdown on May .ldquoOur emergence from lockdown will be faster or slower, depending on the continued success that we have in suppressing the virus, said Ms Sturgeon.Dominic Cummings gives a press conference in May, amid pressure to resignThe following day, Dominic Cummings - the PMrsquos controversial aide - was revealed to have broken lockdown rules by travelling  miles from London to his parentsrsquo home in Durham after he and his we developed coronavirus symptoms.Under pressure to resign, he later gives a press briefing at the Downing Street Rose Garden where he claims to have taken a  minute drive while there with his we and son to Barnard Castle in order to ldquotest his eyesight, which he believed could have been damaged by the infection.On May , Scotland took its first steps out of lockdown with the re-opening of gardening centres and the resumption of some outdoor leisure activities, such as golf and tennis.June saw the introduction of quarantine and lsquoair bridgersquo arrangements for foreign travel, but was also bookended by scandal and tragedy.On June , it emerged that more than , elderly patients had been discharged from Scotlandrsquos hospitals into care homes before mandatory coronavirus testing was introduced on April .Badreddin Abadlla AdamThen, on June , six people were stabbed - including police officer PC David Whyte - at the Park Inn hotel in Glasgow, where asylum seekers were being isolated by the Home Office.Attacker Badreddin Abadlla Adam was shot dead, but the incident sparked calls for an independent inquiry into the conditions faced by asylum seekers during the pandemic.Part Two of the Year in Covid will be published on Saturday January

title: politics-election-government-needs-change-progress
story: However there is a flip side. Being a party politician or staffer, or perhaps worse an activist, tends to tribalise people and render them largely unable to see reason or appreciate nuance.This often leads to unsubstantiated braggery, which hovers around our politics like the smell of spoiled milk. Thatrsquos perpetually annoying. It also leads to emotional decision making, and therefore underperformance of people who, in other walks of le, would be successful.Most damagingly, though, this clouded perspective can often stle good government, with our rulers considering their administration to be performing better than it actually is and therefore not being prepared to change course. In short, they begin to believe their own publicity, and we all suffer.In Scotland, as in all democracies, there is a healthy dose of all of this. But there are also a few examples, on all sides, of politicians and advisers who are able to take a more dispassionate view of the performance of their tribe. These people are of real value ndash theyrsquore the change-makers.The Scottish Government has a good few of these rare beasts in its ranks of ministers and advisers. It is now that they need them.The SNP has been in government in Scotland for almost  years. I am hardly spoiling the upcoming Scottish Parliament election for Herald readers when I say that another five years beckon, perhaps as a majority, perhaps as a minority. And although there are some route maps to either the Conservatives or Labour inhabiting Bute House after the  elections, they are narrow and require the sort of expert steering that neither or those parties have so far shown themselves capable of.So the SNP it will be for  years, for sure, and likely for  years. Itrsquos an astonishingly long time to be in government, and represents the defiance of all accepted political gravity. With this longevity, and in truth with very little competition, it is devilishly dficult to stay fresh, to stay on top of the job, to innovate, to change.Time, then, for these change-makers. Letrsquos forget the opposition hype this is not an incompetent government. It is a government run by a group of extremely intelligent and committed people who, like all governments, can point to some successes and some failures.However, it is a government which is increasingly running into trouble in the key areas which really matter to voters. The recent IpsosMORI STV polling will not have gone unnoticed although trust ratings were high across the board, they were lowest on the issue of our schools.We are not short of old tropes about Scotland having a world leading education system, but we are short of evidence for it. The system is centred on the wishes of councils and unions, which iniably run counter to the needs of pupils and parents, who are often treated as an afterthought, at best, and an inconvenience at worst. Results are mediocre.And it is iniquitousyou want to make it to medical school and be a doctor in Scotland, for instance, there are a huge number of state schools in Scotland where statistics show that outcome is impossible. The ugly truth is that opportunity is maximised only for those children whose parents can afford a house in a good catchment area.And despite the Thursday night clapping and the "Thank You NHS" signs, healthcare is another looming source of trouble. As with schools, the facts render the national narrative delusional.Our NHS has  per cent fewer doctors per head than the OECD average. We have barely half the average number of hospital beds per head. We have less than half the number of MRI scanners, and one-third the number of CT scanners per head.We scrape into the OECD top- for survival rates for major cancers ndash colorectal, breast and cervical. We perform even worse ndash outside the top  ndash in mortality rates for heart attack, haemorrhagic stroke and ischemic stroke.Some fairly radical change is required for the next term of SNP government. It should start with the Cabinet, and not just the people in it, but the structure of it. They have a unique opportunity to do this one-third of the cabinet is standing down at the election.Irsquod reduce the number of cabinet secretaries and expand the number of ministers sitting underneath them. The structure and relationship between cabinet secretaries, ministers, and the special advisers who serve them, has become confused to the detriment of progress.Take rural affairs. The rural economy is bound up in sustainability, climate change and energy, yet these issues are split across, at my count, three ministers and four cabinet secretaries, and thatrsquos before we bring the matter of local authority planning into it. There are other examples, when we get into the weeds of this ndash the splitting of finance and economy for instance.Better to have a top-level cabinet reduced in size to, say, eight secretaries, with an expanded team of ministers with much clearer, more focused, more accountable remits.Being in government is hard. Being in government for more than a couple of decades is harder still. Fundamental renewal is not a concession of failure it is an acknowledgement that progress is impossible without change.Changing structures doesnrsquot change outcomes, but itrsquos a good place to start.bull Andy Maciver is Director of Message MattersOur columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: politics-election-2021-shaping-important-year-recent-history-snp
story: Next Mayrsquos elections will deliver the partyrsquos fourth successive Holyrood administration which means that by  some Scots who werenrsquot born when the SNP first gained power will be having children of their own.In due course political philosophers will soon come to be writing about the SNPrsquos legacy. And unless the Labour Party in Scotland can re-connect with its core working-class communities the SNPrsquos dominion will stretch still further.The party had better hope that Scottish independence is delivered before then, thus enabling it to claim self-determination as its eternal gt to Scotland. Close scrutiny of its political bequest beyond the constitutional question does not yet tell of signicant improvements to the lives of most of its citizens.Certainly, Scotland feels like a warmer and more humane place to be than the current reality of le in England. The politics of Brexit and the darker cultural forces unleashed in its wake has seen our great southern neighbour reduced to a pariah state, still clinging to the frayed threads of empire.Set against this Scotland must seem like a cultural Xanadu: welcoming immigrants providing a haven for refugees and seeking to enable them to live and work here.Meanwhile, Nicola Sturgeon is flirting outrageously with the European Union as England accuses it of unreasonable behaviour throughout a stormy -year marriage and a messy orce.Yet the SNP still has work to doit wants its legacy to be regarded as a positive one for the majority of Scotlandrsquos citizens. Baby boxes and the free tuition grt cannot disguise the reality of working-class communities in Scotlandrsquos densely populated west Central Belt experiencing similar levels of deprivation to those they had to endure for decades before the SNP took office.Only a set of gentle breezes blowing in the SNPrsquos favour has prevented harsher scrutiny of its failure to improve the lives of its poorest citizens. The party has come into its majority at a time when Scottish Labour now resemble little more than a badly-run social work department. The people whom the Tories unearth in Scotland, meanwhile, are a warning to parents currently considering sending their children to a private school. With an opposition as feckless as this Scotland effectively has become a one-party state.Latterly, the SNP has been blessed by Boris Johnsonrsquos annexation of the UK Government. When the Union you wish to leave is run by a man who looks like Worzel Gummidgersquos shady uncle ndash but without the dress sense ndash the odds against the expressed fulfilment of your dream begin to sht in your favour, as theyrsquove been doing consistently in the last  opinion polls.Yet, in spite of such a benign political terrain  is shaping to be the most important year in the recent history of the SNP. Itrsquos the year when wersquoll get to learn how serious the partyrsquos leadership ever was about actual independence.For several years itrsquos been virtually certain that the party will gain an overall majority in favour of independence at the next Scottish election. Now they must show their workings to its own supporters. Itrsquos simply inconceivable that a party with its vast resources in finances, personnel and membership has no other strategy than one which they know must always fail: asking Worzel Gummidgersquos uncle to grant a Section  order.It will be interesting now to see how the partyrsquos newly-constituted NEC, lately freed from the grip of its designer radicals, aims to use its powers. Its immediate task is to force the party leadership actively to pursue an alternative to Section  featuring a determined and well-planned battle in the courts.With the identity extremists in the party now having been isolated and routed, the SNP now must ensure that they are never permitted to infect the party with their misogynistic poison again. It was only a matter of time before the true nature of these people would be exposed to communities with far more pressing concerns around le and death than gender reform. The damage they risked causing to SNP support in these places could have been grievous.Of much wider concern for the SNP is how they dismantle a growing suspicion in the wider radical Yes movement that they harbour an insidious neo-liberal strain in their leadership. These instincts could be observed once more yesterday as it was revealed it will face a legal challenge for its failure to implement a recovery programme in the Firth of Clyde, now ravaged by the activities of big industrial trawling concerns. The same dark forces were present in its failure to curtail driven grouse shooting on Scotlandrsquos vast landed estates. It pays these days for lobbying firms to meet the stf costs of having a presence at SNP conferences.If only the SNP could have found the same sense of purpose they deploy to cosy up to major landed and industrial concerns when trying to protect working-class jobs in Fe and Lewis which depended on the success of the BiFab manufacturing firm. Their abandonment of these communities to the fate of geo-political capitalism was the inevitable consequence of an incoherent renewables strategy, despite enjoying an abundance of natural advantages. A much more competent opposition would have damaged the SNP over this.The party must also use  to free itself from the influence of its pet lobbying firms and reveal the shady nexus of relationships that permit a few very rich and powerful people to influence economic and cultural policy in Scotland. In  the election of a Labour Government with three terms at its disposal held the beguiling promise of a game-changing, economic sht in favour of working-class communities. This was blown in the desire to placate the money-changers of global capitalism.The SNP has a few more years yet to ensure they donrsquot stand accused at the end of their reign of wasting the opportunity to rule in favour of the many and not the few.
